article_title: Max Boot: How Al Qaeda Terrorized Its Way Back in Iraq
article_text: The climactic battles of the American War in Iraq were fought in Anbar Province, with U.S. forces at great cost retaking the city of Fallujah at the end of 2004 and Ramadi, the provincial capital, in 2006-07. The latter success was sparked by an unlikely alliance with tribal fighters that turned around what had been a losing war effort and made possible the success of what became known as "the surge." By 2009, violence had fallen more than 90%, creating an unexpected opportunity to build a stable, democratic and...

twitter.description: In The Wall Street Journal, Max Boot writes that as the country edges closer to civil war, much of the blame goes to Prime Minister Maliki—and the White House.
twitter.title: How Al Qaeda Terrorized Its Way Back in Iraq

article_summary:
By 2009, violence had fallen more than 90%, creating an unexpected opportunity to build a stable, democratic and...
The latter success was sparked by an unlikely alliance with tribal fighters that turned around what had been a losing war effort and made possible the success of what became known as "the surge."
The climactic battles of the American War in Iraq were fought in Anbar Province, with U.S. forces at great cost retaking the city of Fallujah at the end of 2004 and Ramadi, the provincial capital, in 2006-07.
